variable: typical Specific leaf area vs mass
Reference: Lemaire, G., et al. (2008). European Journal of Agronomy, 28(3), 434-447. (Provides SLA context for forage legumes).
Calculation assumes ~48% C mass fraction.

variable: typical Protein carbon mass per unit of leaf area
Reference: Based on high SLN (2-3 gN/m2) from Lemaire et al. (2008) and C3 protein fractions (~75%).
C:N mass ratio of protein ~3.31.

variable: typical Carbon mass ratio of rubisco enzyme to total leaf protein
Reference: Evans, J. R. (1989). Oecologia, 78(1), 9-19. (Standard C3 range).

variable: typical Cholorophyll carbon in mesophyll
Reference: Gitelson, A. A., et al. (2003). Journal of Plant Physiology, 160(3), 271-282. (Context for Chl in C3 crops).
Assumes ~73.6% C in chlorophyll.

variable: typical Maximum carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
unit: umol CO2 s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wilson, K. B., et al. (2000). Agricultural and Forest Meteorology, 104(2), 107-125. (Provides Vcmax data for alfalfa).

variable: typical Maximum electron transport rate at 25oC
unit: umol e- s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wilson, K. B., et al. (2000). Agricultural and Forest Meteorology, 104(2), 107-125. (Provides Jmax data for alfalfa).

variable: Specific chlorophyll activity (at light saturation)
Reference: Calculated as Jmax (180-300) / Chlorophyll Carbon content (~0.22-0.45 gC m-2).

variable: typical annual Gross Primary Production (GPP)
Reference: Avice, J. C., et al. (1997). Agronomie, 17(2), 107-118. (Context for high productivity of multi-cut alfalfa).

variable: typical Axial resistivity per m root length for water uptake
Reference: Meunier, F., et al. (2018). Vadose Zone Journal, 17(1), 170068. (Review including herbaceous dicot hydraulics).
Alfalfa has a deep taproot system.

variable: typical Radial resistance per m2 root surface area for water uptake
Reference: Meunier, F., et al. (2018). Vadose Zone Journal, 17(1), 170068. (Range for herbaceous dicots).

variable: typical Maximum NH4 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Garnett, T., et al. (2001). Plant and Soil, 236(1), 67-75. (General crop N-uptake kinetics).
Derived from dry weight Vmax (e.g., 6-30 umolN gDW-1 h-1).

variable: typical Maximum NO3 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Garnett, T., et al. (2001). Plant and Soil, 236(1), 67-75. (General crop N-uptake kinetics).
Derived from dry weight Vmax (e.g., 4-18 umolN gDW-1 h-1).

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NH4
Reference: Britto, D. T., & Kronzucker, H. J. (2002). Plant, Cell & Environment, 25(6), 687-699. (Typical HATS range).

variable: typical root hair frequency on fine roots
Reference: Epstein, E., & Bloom, A. J. (2005). Mineral Nutrition of Plants. (General dicot root morphology).

variable: typical fine root branching frequency
Reference: Epstein, E., & Bloom, A. J. (2005). Mineral Nutrition of Plants. (General dicot taproot morphology).

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NO3
Reference: Typical HATS range for C3 dicots.
Crawford, N. M., & Glass, A. D. M. (1998). Trends in Plant Science, 3(10), 389-395.

variable: Saturated specific carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
Reference: Sage, R. F., & Seemann, J. R. (1993). Plant Physiology, 102(1), 21-30. (General kcat for C3 crops).

variable: typical Cholorophyll carbon in mesophyll
Reference: Zarco-Tejada, P. J., et al. (2004). Remote Sensing of Environment, 89(2), 189-199. (Source for total chlorophyll range).
Lichtenthaler, H. K., & Babani, F. (2021). Photosynthetica, 60(1), 3-9. (Source for Chl a:b ratio).
PubChem. (n.d.). (Source for molecular formulas and carbon mass fraction).

variable: typical Maximum electron transport rate at 25oC
unit: umol e- s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Warren, C. R., & Adams, M. A. (2001). Plant, Cell & Environment, 24(6), 597-609.
Guan, X. K., et al. (2010). Photosynthetica, 48(3), 329-336.
Jensen, A. M., et al. (2015). Annals of Botany, 116(5), 821–833.

variable: typical annual Gross Primary Production (GPP)
Reference: Mäkelä, A., et al. (2009). Tree Physiology, 29(5), 621-638. (Shows range across boreal/temperate sites).
Ma, J., et al. (2015). Scientific Reports, 5, 10820. (Supports lower end, global average).
Luyssaert, S., et al. (2007). Global Change Biology, 13(12), 2509-2537. (Supports higher end for temperate forests).

variable: typical Protein carbon mass per unit of leaf area
Reference: Walker, A. P., et al. (2014). Ecology and Evolution, 4(22), 4401-4417. (Context for leaf N content).
Evans, J. R. (1989). Oecologia, 78(1), 9-19. (Supports fraction of N in protein).
Jones, D. B. (1931, revised 1941). USDA Circular No. 183. (Source for N-to-protein factor 6.25).
Standard biochemical principles (Supports ~53% C in protein).

variable: typical Axial resistivity per m root length for water uptake
Reference: Derived from inverse of typical axial hydraulic conductivity (kh) values for conifer roots (tracheids), often ranging 1e-14 to 5e-13 m4 s-1 MPa-1.
Sperry, J. S., Hacke, U. G., & Pittermann, J. (2006). Plant, Cell & Environment, 29(3), 364-383. (Review of xylem structure/function, including conifers).
Tyree, M. T., & Ewers, F. W. (1991). New Phytologist, 119(3), 345-360. (Discussion of hydraulic architecture, including conifers).
Calculation requires converting s-1 to h-1 (dividing by 3600).

variable: typical Radial resistance per m2 root surface area for water uptake
Reference: Derived from inverse of typical radial hydraulic conductivity (Lpr) values for woody/conifer roots, often ranging 5e-9 to 5e-8 m s-1 MPa-1.
Steudle, E. (2000). Journal of Experimental Botany, 51(350), 1533-1545. (General review context for root water transport).
Jackson, R. B., et al. (2000). Plant and Soil, 220(1), 1-19. (Review discussing root structure and function, including conifers).
Mycorrhizal influence can significantly alter Lpr/Rr.
Calculation requires converting s-1 to h-1 (dividing by 3600).

variable: typical Maximum carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
unit: umol CO2 s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.
Conifers typically have lower rates per area than C3 crops.

variable: typical Carbon mass ratio of rubisco enzyme to total leaf protein
Reference: Warren, C. R. (2008). Tree Physiology, 28(11), 1585-1599. (Conifers invest less in Rubisco relative to structural/defense compounds).
Evans, J. R. (1989). Oecologia, 78(1), 9-19.

variable: Specific chlorophyll activity (at light saturation)
Reference: Calculated as Jmax (70-150) / Chlorophyll Carbon content (~0.20-0.42 gC m-2).

variable: typical Specific leaf area vs mass
Reference: Needles are very dense (low SLA).
Calculation based on SLA_DM of 0.002-0.01 m2/gDM and Carbon fraction ~0.50 gC/gDM.

variable: typical Maximum NH4 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Woody plants generally have lower Vmax per gram than herbaceous.
Derived from dry weight Vmax (e.g., 2-12 umolN gDW-1 h-1) and root carbon fraction (~45%).
Garnett, T. P., et al. (2003). Plant and Soil, 248(1-2), 1-15.

variable: typical Maximum NO3 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Derived from dry weight Vmax (e.g., 1-9 umolN gDW-1 h-1) and root carbon fraction (~45%).
Garnett, T. P., et al. (2003). Plant and Soil, 248(1-2), 1-15.

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NH4
Reference: Britto, D. T., & Kronzucker, H. J. (2002). Plant, Cell & Environment, 25(6), 687-699.

variable: typical root hair frequency on fine roots
Reference: Derived from typical densities of 10-80 hairs/mm.
Often lower than grasses and heavily dependent on mycorrhizal associations (which act in place of root hairs).

variable: typical fine root branching frequency
Reference: Derived from typical densities of 2-15 laterals/cm.
Highly variable based on root order and soil exploration strategy.

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NO3
Reference: Values for conifers are significantly higher than crops.
Kronzucker, H. J., et al. (1999). Plant Physiology, 119(3), 1041-1047. (reports ~340-350 uM for spruce/pine).

variable: Saturated specific carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
Reference: Warren, C. R. (2008). Tree Physiology, 28(11), 1585-1599. (Conifer kcat is often lower than C3 angiosperms).

variable: typical Specific leaf area vs mass
Reference: Wright, I. J., et al. (2004). Nature, 428(6985), 821-827. (High SLA typical of herbaceous legumes).
Calculation assumes ~48% C mass fraction.

variable: typical Protein carbon mass per unit of leaf area
Reference: High N content due to N-fixation, but thinner leaves than alfalfa.
Based on SLN of ~1.3-2.8 gN/m2 and ~75% protein-N.

variable: typical Carbon mass ratio of rubisco enzyme to total leaf protein
Reference: Evans, J. R. (1989). Oecologia, 78(1), 9-19. (Standard C3 range).

variable: typical Cholorophyll carbon in mesophyll
Reference: Similar to other productive C3 dicots; ~250-550 mg/m2 total chlorophyll.

variable: typical Maximum carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
unit: umol CO2 s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Woledge, J., & Dennis, W. D. (1982). Annals of Botany, 50(1), 25-35. (Context for white clover photosynthesis).

variable: typical Maximum electron transport rate at 25oC
unit: umol e- s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Coupled to high Vcmax; Wullschleger (1993) general C3 range.

variable: Specific chlorophyll activity (at light saturation)
Reference: Calculated as Jmax (150-260) / Chlorophyll Carbon content (~0.18-0.40 gC m-2).

variable: typical annual Gross Primary Production (GPP)
Reference: High productivity, often mixed in productive pastures (e.g., in grass/clover mixes).
Scurlock, J. M. O., et al. (2002). Global Change Biology, 8(1), 20-36.

variable: typical Axial resistivity per m root length for water uptake
Reference: Meunier, F., et al. (2018). Vadose Zone Journal, 17(1), 170068. (General herbaceous dicot).

variable: typical Radial resistance per m2 root surface area for water uptake
Reference: Meunier, F., et al. (2018). Vadose Zone Journal, 17(1), 170068. (General herbaceous dicot).

variable: typical Maximum NH4 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: General range for herbaceous dicots.

variable: typical Maximum NO3 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: General range for herbaceous dicots.

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NH4
Reference: Typical HATS range.

variable: typical root hair frequency on fine roots
Reference: Epstein, E., & Bloom, A. J. (2005). Mineral Nutrition of Plants. (General dicot range).

variable: typical fine root branching frequency
Reference: Epstein, E., & Bloom, A. J. (2005). Mineral Nutrition of Plants. (General dicot range).

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NO3
Reference: Typical HATS range for C3 dicots.
Crawford, N. M., & Glass, A. D. M. (1998). Trends in Plant Science, 3(10), 389-395.

variable: Saturated specific carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
Reference: Sage, R. F., & Seemann, J. R. (1993). Plant Physiology, 102(1), 21-30. (General kcat for C3 crops).

variable: typical Specific leaf area vs mass
Reference: Poorter, H., et al. (2009). New Phytologist, 182(3), 565-588.
Cotton leaves are relatively thick/leathery.
Calculation based on SLA_DM of 0.015-0.03 m2/gDM and Carbon fraction ~0.48 gC/gDM.

variable: typical Protein carbon mass per unit of leaf area
Reference: Based on SLN of 1.3-2.5 gN/m2. Pettigrew, W. T. (1999). Agronomy Journal, 91(6), 962-966.

variable: typical Carbon mass ratio of rubisco enzyme to total leaf protein
Reference: Evans, J. R. (1989). Oecologia, 78(1), 9-19. (Standard C3 range).

variable: typical Cholorophyll carbon in mesophyll
Reference: Gitelson, A. A., et al. (2003). Journal of Plant Physiology, 160(3), 271-282. (Range for C3 crops).

variable: typical Maximum carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
unit: umol CO2 s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.

variable: typical Maximum electron transport rate at 25oC
unit: umol e- s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.

variable: Specific chlorophyll activity (at light saturation)
Reference: Calculated as Jmax (150-240) / Chlorophyll Carbon content (~0.20-0.40 gC m-2).

variable: typical annual Gross Primary Production (GPP)
Reference: Productive C3 crop, but partitioning C to fiber.
Snow, V. O., et al. (2005). Field Crops Research, 91(2-3), 195-212.

variable: typical Axial resistivity per m root length for water uptake
Reference: Meunier, F., et al. (2018). Vadose Zone Journal, 17(1), 170068. (General herbaceous dicot).

variable: typical Radial resistance per m2 root surface area for water uptake
Reference: Meunier, F., et al. (2018). Vadose Zone Journal, 17(1), 170068. (General herbaceous dicot).

variable: typical Maximum NH4 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Derived from general dicot Vmax values (e.g., 4.5-27 umolN gDW-1 h-1).

variable: typical Maximum NO3 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Derived from general dicot Vmax values (e.g., 3.5-16 umolN gDW-1 h-1).

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NH4
Reference: Typical HATS range.

variable: typical root hair frequency on fine roots
Reference: Epstein, E., & Bloom, A. J. (2005). Mineral Nutrition of Plants. (General dicot range).

variable: typical fine root branching frequency
Reference: Epstein, E., & Bloom, A. J. (2005). Mineral Nutrition of Plants. (General dicot range).

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NO3
Reference: Typical HATS range for C3 dicots.
ResearchGate. (2025). Nitrogen uptake kinetics in... cotton. (Mentions low Km for HATS).

variable: Saturated specific carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
Reference: Sage, R. F., & Seemann, J. R. (1993). Plant Physiology, 102(1), 21-30. (General kcat for C3 crops).

variable: typical Axial resistivity per m root length for water uptake
Reference: Derived from inverse of typical axial hydraulic conductivity (kh) values for maize, often ranging 1e-12 to 1e-11 m4 s-1 MPa-1.
Doussan, C., Pagès, L., & Vercambre, G. (1998). Annals of Botany, 81(2), 225-232. (Provides kh values used in maize models).
Ahmed, M. A., et al. (2018). Plant Physiology, 177(2), 658-673. (Study on maize root hydraulics).
Calculation requires converting s-1 to h-1 (dividing by 3600).

variable: typical Radial resistance per m2 root surface area for water uptake
Reference: Derived from inverse of typical radial hydraulic conductivity (Lpr) values for maize, often ranging 1e-8 to 1e-7 m s-1 MPa-1.
Hachez, C., et al. (2012). Plant Physiology, 160(1), 478-490. (Study on maize aquaporins and Lpr).
Steudle, E. (2000). Journal of Experimental Botany, 51(350), 1533-1545. (Review context).
Calculation requires converting s-1 to h-1 (dividing by 3600).

variable: typical Intercellular-to-atmospheric CO2 concentration ratio (Ci/Ca)
Reference: von Caemmerer, S., & Furbank, R. T. (2003). Photosynthesis Research, 77(2-3), 191-211. (Review of C4 photosynthesis mechanisms explaining low Ci).
Taiz, L., Zeiger, E., Møller, I. M., & Murphy, A. (2015). Plant Physiology and Development (6th ed.). Sinauer Associates. (Textbook comparing C3 and C4 Ci/Ca ratios).
Gas exchange studies on Zea mays consistently show low Ci relative to Ca under optimal conditions.

variable: typical Cholorophyll carbon in bundle sheath
Reference: Derived from typical total leaf chlorophyll (300-600 mg m-2), estimated fraction in bundle sheath (10-25%), and high Chl a/b ratio (using C fraction ~73.9%).
Edwards, G. E., & Walker, D. A. (1983). C3, C4: mechanisms, and cellular and environmental regulation, of photosynthesis. University of California Press.
Ghannoum, O., et al. (2005). Plant, Cell & Environment, 28(8), 980-993. (Discusses chlorophyll partitioning in C4 grasses).

variable: typical Cholorophyll carbon in mesophyll
Reference: Derived from typical total leaf chlorophyll (300-600 mg m-2), estimated fraction in mesophyll (75-90%), and C3-like Chl a/b ratio (using C fraction ~73.6%).
Edwards, G. E., & Walker, D. A. (1983). C3, C4: mechanisms, and cellular and environmental regulation, of photosynthesis. University of California Press.
Ghannoum, O., et al. (2005). Plant, Cell & Environment, 28(8), 980-993. (Discusses chlorophyll partitioning in C4 grasses).

variable: typical Protein carbon mass per unit of leaf area
Reference: Calculated value based on typical Specific Leaf Nitrogen (SLN) of 1.0 gN m-2, a protein-N fraction of 33%, and a C:N mass ratio of ~3.31.
C:N ratio derived from standard biochemical principles (Protein ~53% C, ~16% N).
SLN reference: Muchow, R. C. (1988). Field Crops Research, 18(1), 17-30.
Protein-N fraction reference: Based on C4 physiology (lower Rubisco content).

variable: typical Maximum carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
unit: umol CO2 s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162. (Indicates lower Vcmax for C4 vs C3).
Kattge, J., et al. (2011). Global Change Biology, 17(9), 2905-2935. (TRY database context).
C4 plants concentrate CO2, requiring less Rubisco and thus having a lower Vcmax per leaf area than C3s.

variable: typical Maximum electron transport rate at 25oC
unit: umol e- s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.
C4 photosynthesis has an additional ATP demand, but Jmax is often comparable to or slightly higher than C3 grasses to support this.

variable: typical Carbon mass ratio of rubisco enzyme to total leaf protein
Reference: Feller et al. (2008). J Exp Botany, 59(7), 1615-1624. (Notes Rubisco is ~5-9% of total leaf N in C4 plants).
C4 plants concentrate CO2, requiring far less Rubisco protein than C3 plants.
Assumes C:N ratio of Rubisco is similar to other proteins, so N-fraction is proxy for C-fraction.

variable: Specific chlorophyll activity (at light saturation)
Reference: Calculated as Jmax (100-250) / Chlorophyll Carbon content (~0.19-0.51 gC m-2).
Reflects high electron transport rates relative to total chlorophyll.

variable: typical Specific leaf area vs mass
Reference: Poorter, H., et al. (2009). New Phytologist, 182(3), 565-588. (General range for herbaceous plants).
Maize leaves are relatively thick, similar to other productive grasses.
Calculation based on typical SLA_DM of 0.015-0.03 m2/gDM and Carbon fraction of ~0.48 gC/gDM.

variable: typical annual Gross Primary Production (GPP)
Reference: Suyker, A. E., & Verma, S. B. (2009). Agricultural and Forest Meteorology, 149(3-4), 445-452. (Shows high seasonal GPP in maize).
C4 crops are among the most productive ecosystems on Earth during their growing season.
Range represents high-productivity agricultural settings.

variable: typical Maximum NH4 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Derived from dry weight Vmax (e.g., 5-25 umolN gDW-1 h-1) and root carbon fraction (~40-45%).
Garnett, T., et al. (2001). Plant and Soil, 236(1), 67-75. (Study on maize N uptake kinetics).
Epstein, E., & Bloom, A. J. (2005). Mineral Nutrition of Plants. (General ranges).

variable: typical Maximum NO3 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Derived from dry weight Vmax (e.g., 2-12 umolN gDW-1 h-1) and root carbon fraction (~40-45%).
Garnett, T., et al. (2001). Plant and Soil, 236(1), 67-75. (Study on maize N uptake kinetics).
Crawford, N. M., & Glass, A. D. M. (1998). Trends in Plant Science, 3(10), 389-395.

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NH4
Reference: Britto, D. T., & Kronzucker, H. J. (2002). Plant, Cell & Environment, 25(6), 687-699.
Value is characteristic of High-Affinity Transport Systems (HATS) common across many plants, including maize.

variable: typical root hair frequency on fine roots
Reference: Derived from typical densities of 40-200 hairs/mm.
Ma, Z., et al. (2001). Plant Physiology, 127(3), 941-951. (Discusses maize root hair development).
General plant anatomy texts.

variable: typical fine root branching frequency
Reference: Derived from typical densities of 2-10 laterals/cm.
Pagès, L., et al. (2004). Plant and Soil, 258(1), 1-21.
Maize has a highly branched fibrous root system.

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NO3
Reference: York, L. M., et al. (2016). Journal of Experimental Botany, 67(16), 4931-4944. (Reports range of 2.7-52.2 uM).

variable: Saturated specific carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
Reference: Sage, R. F. (2002). Oecologia, 132(4), 481-495. (C4 kcat is generally higher than C3).

variable: typical Specific leaf area vs mass
Reference: Poorter, H., et al. (2009). New Phytologist, 182(3), 565-588.
General range for temperate C3 grasses.

variable: typical Protein carbon mass per unit of leaf area
Reference: Based on typical SLN for C3 cereals (1.0-2.5 gN/m2), 75% protein-N, and ~3.31 C:N ratio.
Peltonen-Sainio, P., et al. (2007). Agronomy Journal, 99(2), 441-449.

variable: typical Carbon mass ratio of rubisco enzyme to total leaf protein
Reference: Standard range for C3 plants (e.g., Evans, 1989).

variable: typical Cholorophyll carbon in mesophyll
Reference: Typical range for C3 cereals, derived from 200-500 mg/m2 total chlorophyll.
Assumes ~73.6% C in chlorophyll.

variable: typical Maximum carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
unit: umol CO2 s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.
Similar to winter wheat.

variable: typical Maximum electron transport rate at 25oC
unit: umol e- s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.
Similar to winter wheat.

variable: Specific chlorophyll activity (at light saturation)
Reference: Calculated as Jmax (120-220) / Chlorophyll Carbon content (~0.15-0.37 gC m-2).

variable: typical annual Gross Primary Production (GPP)
Reference: Reflects typical GPP for temperate C3 annual crops.
Amiro, B. D., et al. (2006). Agricultural and Forest Meteorology, 139(3-4), 163-176.

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NH4
Reference: Typical HATS range, similar to other C3 grasses.
Britto, D. T., & Kronzucker, H. J. (2002). Plant, Cell & Environment, 25(6), 687-699.

variable: typical Axial resistivity per m root length for water uptake
Reference: Similar to other C3 grasses (e.g., wheat, barley).
Steudle, E. (2000). Journal of Experimental Botany, 51(350), 1533-1545.

variable: typical Radial resistance per m2 root surface area for water uptake
Reference: Similar to other C3 grasses.
Steudle, E. (2000). Journal of Experimental Botany, 51(350), 1533-1545.

variable: typical Maximum NH4 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Similar to other C3 grasses.
Derived from typical Vmax values on dry weight basis (5-20 umolN gDW-1 h-1).

variable: typical Maximum NO3 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Similar to other C3 grasses.
Derived from typical Vmax values on dry weight basis (2-10 umolN gDW-1 h-1).

variable: typical root hair frequency on fine roots
Reference: Dittmer, H. J. (1937). American Journal of Botany, 24(7), 417-420.

variable: typical fine root branching frequency
Reference: Fibrous root system typical of grasses.

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NO3
Reference: Typical HATS range for C3 cereals, similar to wheat/barley.
Epstein, E., & Bloom, A. J. (2005). Mineral Nutrition of Plants.

variable: Saturated specific carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
Reference: Sage, R. F., & Seemann, J. R. (1993). Plant Physiology, 102(1), 21-30. (General kcat for C3 crops).

variable: typical Axial resistivity per m root length for water uptake
Reference: Derived from inverse of typical axial hydraulic conductivity (kh) values for sedges/monocots in moist habitats, potentially slightly lower than some grasses (e.g., 4.5e-13 to 4.5e-12 m4 s-1 MPa-1).
Steudle, E. (2000). Journal of Experimental Botany, 51(350), 1533-1545. (General review context for monocot root hydraulics).
Literature on specific sedge species (e.g., Carex) and wetland plants.

variable: typical Radial resistance per m2 root surface area for water uptake
Reference: Derived from inverse of typical radial hydraulic conductivity (Lpr) values for sedges/monocots, often ranging 7e-9 to 9e-8 m s-1 MPa-1.
Steudle, E. (2000). Journal of Experimental Botany, 51(350), 1533-1545. (General review context for monocot root hydraulics).
Miyamoto, N., et al. (2001). Plant Physiology, 125(4), 1915-1927. (Example study showing Lpr in rice, another wetland monocot).
Adaptations to wet soils might influence Lpr/Rr compared to upland grasses.
Calculation requires converting s-1 to h-1 (dividing by 3600).

variable: typical Cholorophyll carbon in mesophyll
Reference: Assuming typical C3 grass chlorophyll ranges (~200-550 mg m-2) and C fraction (~73.6%).
Values are for C3 sedges, which are most common.

variable: typical Maximum electron transport rate at 25oC
unit: umol e- s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Similar to other productive C3 grasses.
Starr, G., et al. (2004). Oecologia, 140(2), 241-250.

variable: typical annual Gross Primary Production (GPP)
Reference: Sedges in wetlands/tundra can be highly productive.
Oechel, W. C., et al. (1998). Arctic and Alpine Research, 30(3), 254-260.

variable: typical Protein carbon mass per unit of leaf area
Reference: Assuming similar to productive C3 grass (e.g., SLN 1.0-2.5 gN/m2).

variable: typical Specific leaf area vs mass
Reference: Poorter, H., et al. (2009). New Phytologist, 182(3), 565-588.
Similar to C3 grasses, though some wetland species have high SLA.

variable: typical Carbon mass ratio of rubisco enzyme to total leaf protein
Reference: Standard range for C3 plants.

variable: typical Maximum carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
unit: umol CO2 s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Similar to productive C3 grasses.
Starr, G., et al. (2004). Oecologia, 140(2), 241-250.

variable: Specific chlorophyll activity (at light saturation)
Reference: Calculated as Jmax (100-200) / Chlorophyll Carbon content (~0.15-0.37 gC m-2).

variable: typical Maximum NH4 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Sedges, especially in wetlands, are often adapted to high NH4+ availability.
Derived from dry weight Vmax (e.g., 5-25 umolN gDW-1 h-1) and root carbon fraction (~40-45%).

variable: typical Maximum NO3 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Similar to C3 grass.

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NH4
Reference: Typical HATS range.

variable: typical root hair frequency on fine roots
Reference: Dittmer, H. J. (1937). American Journal of Botany, 24(7), 417-420.

variable: typical fine root branching frequency
Reference: Fibrous root system typical of grasses.

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NO3
Reference: Typical HATS range for C3 monocots.

variable: Saturated specific carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
Reference: Assuming typical C3 kcat (e.g., Sage & Seemann, 1993).

variable: typical Axial resistivity per m root length for water uptake
Reference: Derived from inverse of typical axial hydraulic conductivity (kh) values for herbaceous dicots like soybean, often ranging 1e-13 to 1e-12 m4 s-1 MPa-1.
Meunier, F., et al. (2018). Vadose Zone Journal, 17(1), 170068. (Review including soybean hydraulic properties).
Bramley, H., et al. (2009). Plant Physiology, 150(1), 348-364. (Compares dicot - lupin - vs monocot hydraulics).
Calculation requires converting s-1 to h-1 (dividing by 3600).

variable: typical Radial resistance per m2 root surface area for water uptake
Reference: Derived from inverse of typical radial hydraulic conductivity (Lpr) values for soybean/herbaceous dicots, often ranging 2e-9 to 2e-8 m s-1 MPa-1.
Steudle, E. (2000). Journal of Experimental Botany, 51(350), 1531-1542. (General review context).
Maurel, C., et al. (2015). Annual Review of Plant Biology, 66, 195-220. (Review covering aquaporins and Lpr variability).
Calculation requires converting s-1 to h-1 (dividing by 3600).

variable: typical Cholorophyll carbon in mesophyll
Reference: Derived from typical total leaf chlorophyll (300-600 mg m-2) and C3 carbon fraction (~73.6%).
Gitelson, A. A., et al. (2003). Journal of Plant Physiology, 160(3), 271-282. (Provides chlorophyll data for various crops including soybean).
PubChem. (n.d.). (Source for molecular formulas and carbon mass fraction).

variable: typical Protein carbon mass per unit of leaf area
Reference: Calculated value based on typical Specific Leaf Nitrogen (SLN) of 1.5 gN m-2, a protein-N fraction of 75%, and a C:N mass ratio of ~3.31.
C:N ratio derived from standard biochemical principles (Protein ~53% C, ~16% N).
SLN reference: Sinclair, T. R., & Horie, T. (1989). Crop Sciences, 29(1), 90-95.
Protein-N fraction reference: e.g., Evans (1989). Oecologia, 78(1), 9-19.

variable: typical Maximum carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
unit: umol CO2 s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.
Kattge, J., et al. (2011). Global Change Biology, 17(9), 2905-2935.
Values typical for high-N, productive C3 crops.

variable: typical Maximum electron transport rate at 25oC
unit: umol e- s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.
Reflects high photosynthetic capacity, tightly coupled to Vcmax.

variable: typical Carbon mass ratio of rubisco enzyme to total leaf protein
Reference: Evans, J. R. (1989). Oecologia, 78(1), 9-19.
Typical range for C3 plants, similar to C3 grass.

variable: Specific chlorophyll activity (at light saturation)
Reference: Calculated as Jmax (150-250) / Chlorophyll Carbon content (~0.22-0.44 gC m-2).

variable: typical Specific leaf area vs mass
Reference: Poorter, H., et al. (2009). New Phytologist, 182(3), 565-588.
Calculation based on typical SLA_DM of 0.015-0.035 m2/gDM and Carbon fraction of ~0.48 gC/gDM.

variable: typical annual Gross Primary Production (GPP)
Reference: Reflects high productivity of C3 crops during the growing season.
Suyker, A. E., et al. (2005). Agricultural and Forest Meteorology, 132(3-4), 216-229.

variable: typical Maximum NH4 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Derived from dry weight Vmax (e.g., 6-30 umolN gDW-1 h-1) and root carbon fraction (~40-45%).
General values for herbaceous dicots.

variable: typical Maximum NO3 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Derived from dry weight Vmax (e.g., 4-18 umolN gDW-1 h-1) and root carbon fraction (~40-45%).

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NH4
Reference: Typical HATS range, similar to C3 grass.

variable: typical root hair frequency on fine roots
Reference: Derived from typical densities of 30-150 hairs/mm.
Dicots often have lower root hair density than grasses.

variable: typical fine root branching frequency
Reference: Derived from typical densities of 5-20 laterals/cm.
Reflects taproot system with extensive lateral branching.

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NO3
Reference: Typical HATS range for C3 dicots.
NRT1.1 transporter shows affinity in this range (e.g., ~40 uM).

variable: Saturated specific carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
Reference: Sage, R. F., & Seemann, J. R. (1993). Plant Physiology, 102(1), 21-30. (General kcat for C3 crops).

variable: typical Specific leaf area vs mass
Reference: Poorter, H., et al. (2009). New Phytologist, 182(3), 565-588. (General range for C3 grasses).

variable: typical Protein carbon mass per unit of leaf area
Reference: Based on SLN of 1.0-2.5 gN/m2, 75% protein-N, and ~3.31 C:N ratio.
Dreccer, M. F., et al. (2000). Field Crops Research, 67(3), 209-224.

variable: typical Carbon mass ratio of rubisco enzyme to total leaf protein
Reference: Evans, J. R. (1989). Oecologia, 78(1), 9-19. (Standard C3 range).

variable: typical Cholorophyll carbon in mesophyll
Reference: Typical range for C3 cereals, derived from 200-500 mg/m2 total chlorophyll.

variable: typical Maximum carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
unit: umol CO2 s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.
Amdall, J., et al. (2018). Field Crops Research, 221, 135-144.

variable: typical Maximum electron transport rate at 25oC
unit: umol e- s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.

variable: Specific chlorophyll activity (at light saturation)
Reference: Calculated as Jmax (120-220) / Chlorophyll Carbon content (~0.15-0.37 gC m-2).

variable: typical annual Gross Primary Production (GPP)
Reference: Typical for annual C3 crops.
Amiro, B. D., et al. (2006). Agricultural and Forest Meteorology, 139(3-4), 163-176.

variable: typical Axial resistivity per m root length for water uptake
Reference: Similar to C3 grass.
Steudle, E. (2000). Journal of Experimental Botany, 51(350), 1533-1545.

variable: typical Radial resistance per m2 root surface area for water uptake
Reference: Similar to C3 grass.
Steudle, E. (2000). Journal of Experimental Botany, 51(350), 1533-1545.

variable: typical Maximum NH4 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Similar to C3 grass.
Derived from typical Vmax values on dry weight basis (5-20 umolN gDW-1 h-1).

variable: typical Maximum NO3 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Similar to C3 grass.
Derived from typical Vmax values on dry weight basis (2-10 umolN gDW-1 h-1).

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NH4
Reference: Typical HATS range.

variable: typical root hair frequency on fine roots
Reference: Dittmer, H. J. (1937). American Journal of Botany, 24(7), 417-420.

variable: typical fine root branching frequency
Reference: Similar to C3 grass.

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NO3
Reference: Typical HATS range for C3 cereals.
Epstein, E., & Bloom, A. J. (2005). Mineral Nutrition of Plants.

variable: Saturated specific carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
Reference: Sage, R. F., & Seemann, J. R. (1993). Plant Physiology, 102(1), 21-30. (General kcat for C3 crops).

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NH4
Reference: Britto, D. T., & Kronzucker, H. J. (2002). Plant, Cell & Environment, 25(6), 687-699. (Review on NH4+ toxicity and transport, discusses Km values for HATS).

Epstein, E., & Bloom, A. J. (2005). Mineral Nutrition of Plants: Principles and Perspectives (2nd ed.). Sinauer Associates. (Textbook covering nutrient uptake kinetics, including typical Km ranges for HATS).
Specific studies on grasses (e.g., Lolium, Hordeum) generally report Km values for high-affinity NH4+ uptake within this range.

variable: typical Axial resistivity per m root length for water uptake
Reference: Derived from inverse of typical axial hydraulic conductivity (kh) values for grasses, often ranging 5e-13 to 5e-12 m4 s-1 MPa-1.
Steudle, E. (2000). Journal of Experimental Botany, 51(350), 1533-1545. (Review discussing axial and radial water transport components and typical conductivity ranges).
Sanderson, J. (1983). Journal of Experimental Botany, 34(3), 227-248. (Study measuring hydraulic conductivity in barley roots, providing examples of kh values).
Calculation requires converting s-1 to h-1 (dividing by 3600).

variable: typical Radial resistance per m2 root surface area for water uptake
Reference: Derived from inverse of typical radial hydraulic conductivity (Lpr) values for grasses/herbaceous plants, often ranging 1e-8 to 1e-7 m s-1 MPa-1.
Steudle, E. (2000). Journal of Experimental Botany, 51(350), 1533-1545. (Review discussing radial transport, aquaporins, and typical Lpr ranges).
Bramley, H., et al. (2009). Plant, Cell & Environment, 32(9), 1234-1246. (Provides Lpr values for different grass species under varying conditions).
Calculation requires converting s-1 to h-1 (dividing by 3600).

variable: typical Maximum NH4 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Derived from typical Vmax values on dry weight basis (5-20 umolN gDW-1 h-1) and root carbon fraction (~40-45%).
Epstein, E., & Bloom, A. J. (2005). Mineral Nutrition of Plants: Principles and Perspectives (2nd ed.). Sinauer Associates. (General ranges for Vmax).
Jackson, L. E., et al. (1993). Plant, Cell & Environment, 16(5), 567-577. (Example study measuring Vmax in grasses).
Calculation: Vmax_gC = Vmax_gDW / (gC/gDW fraction).

variable: typical Maximum NO3 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Derived from typical Vmax values on dry weight basis (2-10 umolN gDW-1 h-1) and root carbon fraction (~40-45%).
Epstein, E., & Bloom, A. J. (2005). Mineral Nutrition of Plants: Principles and Perspectives (2nd ed.). Sinauer Associates. (General ranges for Vmax, typically lower for NO3- HATS than NH4+).
Crawford, N. M., & Glass, A. D. M. (1998). Trends in Plant Science, 3(10), 389-395. (Review of nitrate uptake systems).
Calculation: Vmax_gC = Vmax_gDW / (gC/gDW fraction).

variable: typical root hair frequency on fine roots
Reference: Derived from typical densities of 50-300 hairs/mm.
Dittmer, H. J. (1937). American Journal of Botany, 24(7), 417-420. (Classic study providing high-end estimates for grass root hairs).
Ge, Z., et al. (2000). Plant and Soil, 218(1), 159-170. (Discusses root hair responses to P availability).
General plant anatomy and physiology texts (e.g., Esau's Plant Anatomy).

variable: typical fine root branching frequency
Reference: Derived from typical densities of 1-10 laterals/cm.
Fitter, A. H. (1987). New Phytologist, 106(Supplement), 87-101. (Provides examples for Poa annua).
Pagès, L., et al. (2004). Plant and Soil, 258(1), 1-21. (Discusses variability in branching density).
Range reflects variation with root order and soil conditions.

variable: Specific chlorophyll activity (at light saturation)
Reference: Calculated as Jmax / Chlorophyll Carbon content.
Jmax range (60-140 umol e- m-2 s-1) from Wullschleger (1993), Kattge et al. (2011).
Chlorophyll Carbon range (0.15-0.40 gC m-2) derived from general C3 grass values.

variable: typical Specific leaf area vs mass
Reference: General range for C3 grasses, encompassing temperate and other types.
Poorter, H., et al. (2009). New Phytologist, 182(3), 565-588.

variable: typical Protein carbon mass per unit of leaf area
Reference: Broad range covering different nutrient statuses.
Based on SLN of ~1.0-3.0 gN/m2, 75% protein-N, and ~3.31 C:N ratio.

variable: typical Carbon mass ratio of rubisco enzyme to total leaf protein
Reference: Evans, J. R. (1989). Oecologia, 78(1), 9-19.

variable: typical Cholorophyll carbon in mesophyll
Reference: General range for C3 grasses, ~200-550 mg/m2 total chlorophyll.
Assumes ~73.6% C in chlorophyll.

variable: typical Maximum carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
unit: umol CO2 s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.

variable: typical Maximum electron transport rate at 25oC
unit: umol e- s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.

variable: typical annual Gross Primary Production (GPP)
Reference: Broad range covering natural grasslands (lower end) to productive pastures (higher end).
Scurlock, J. M. O., et al. (2002). Global Change Biology, 8(1), 20-36.

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NO3
Reference: Crawford, N. M., & Glass, A. D. M. (1998). Trends in Plant Science, 3(10), 389-395. (Review of HATS/LATS systems).
Epstein, E., & Bloom, A. J. (2005). Mineral Nutrition of Plants: Principles and Perspectives (2nd ed.). (General textbook range for HATS).

variable: Saturated specific carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
Reference: Sage, R. F., & Seemann, J. R. (1993). Plant Physiology, 102(1), 21-30. (General kcat for C3 crops).

variable: typical Specific leaf area vs mass
Reference: Wright, I. J., et al. (2004). Nature, 428(6985), 821-827. (General context for high SLA in grasses).
Poorter, H., et al. (2009). New Phytologist, 182(3), 565-588. (Supports SLA range for herbaceous plants in productive environments).
Poorter, H., & Villar, R. (1997). Plant resource allocation. Academic Press. (Supports carbon fraction of dry mass ~45-50%).
Calculation based on typical SLA_DM of 0.02-0.04 m2/gDM and Carbon fraction of ~0.48 gC/gDM.

variable: typical Protein carbon mass per unit of leaf area
Reference: Plant trait databases (e.g., TRY) and general plant physiology literature support leaf N area for productive C3 grasses in the range of 1.0-2.5 g N m⁻².
Evans, J. R. (1989). Oecologia, 78(1), 9-19. (Supports fraction of N in protein ~70-80%).
Jones, D. B. (1931, revised 1941). USDA Circular No. 183. (Source for N-to-protein factor 6.25).
Standard biochemical principles (Supports ~53% C in protein).
Calculation combines these typical ranges.

variable: typical Carbon mass ratio of rubisco enzyme to total leaf protein
Reference: BioNumbers BNID 110003, citing Feller et al. (2008). J Exp Botany, 59(7), 1615-1624. (States Rubisco up to 50% of soluble leaf protein in C3 plants).
Evans, J. R. (1989). Oecologia, 78(1), 9-19. (Provides context on partitioning N between soluble and insoluble protein fractions).
Calculation assumes soluble protein is ~50-75% of total protein, leading to Rubisco being ~25-40% of total protein mass.
Assumption that carbon mass fraction is similar for Rubisco and the total protein pool (~53%), making the protein mass ratio approximately equal to the protein carbon mass ratio.

variable: typical Cholorophyll carbon in mesophyll
Reference: General plant physiology literature and trait databases (e.g., TRY) support total chlorophyll ranges of 200-500 mg m⁻² for C3 grasses in productive environments.
PubChem. (n.d.). (Source for molecular formulas and carbon mass fraction ~73.6%).
Calculation based on typical chlorophyll range and carbon fraction.

variable: typical Maximum carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
unit: umol CO2 s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162. (Provides a broad synthesis of Vcmax across plant types).
Kattge, J., et al. (2011). Global Change Biology, 17(9), 2905-2935. (TRY database paper, showing trait distributions including Vcmax for grasses).
Literature on specific temperate C3 grasses (e.g., Lolium, Festuca) often reports values within this range, influenced by N availability and light.
Range reflects generally high capacity in favorable temperate oceanic conditions.

variable: typical Maximum electron transport rate at 25oC
unit: umol e- s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.
Reflects high N and favorable conditions.

variable: typical annual Gross Primary Production (GPP)
Reference: High end of C3 grass productivity due to favorable moisture and temperature.
Scurlock, J. M. O., et al. (2002). Global Change Biology, 8(1), 20-36.

Reference: Calculated as Jmax (120-220) / Chlorophyll Carbon content (~0.15-0.37 gC m-2).

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NO3
Reference: Typical HATS range, same as base C3 grass.

variable: Saturated specific carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
Reference: Sage, R. F., & Seemann, J. R. (1993). Plant Physiology, 102(1), 21-30. (General kcat for C3 crops).

Reference: Poorter, H., et al. (2009). New Phytologist, 182(3), 565-588.
General range for temperate C3 cereals like wheat and oats.

Reference: Based on SLN of 1.0-2.5 gN/m2, 75% protein-N, and ~3.31 C:N ratio.

Reference: Evans, J. R. (1989). Oecologia, 78(1), 9-19. (Standard C3 range).

Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.

Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.

Reference: Calculated as Jmax (120-220) / Chlorophyll Carbon content (~0.15-0.37 gC m-2).

Reference: Typical for annual C3 crops.

Reference: Similar to C3 grass (e.g., wheat, oats).

variable: typical Radial resistance per m2 root surface area for water uptake
Reference: Similar to C3 grass (e.g., wheat, oats).

Reference: Similar to C3 grass.

variable: typical Maximum NO3 uptake rate (Vmax)
Reference: Similar to C3 grass.

Reference: Dittmer, H. J. (1937). American Journal of Botany, 24(7), 417-420.

Reference: Sage, R. F., & Seemann, J. R. (1993). Plant Physiology, 102(1), 21-30. (General kcat for C3 crops).

Reference: Poorter, H., et al. (2009). New Phytologist, 182(3), 565-588.
Range typical for productive C4 grasses (e.g., Miscanthus, Panicum) with relatively tough leaves.
Calculation based on SLA_DM of 0.012-0.025 m2/gDM and Carbon fraction ~0.48 gC/gDM.

variable: typical Protein carbon mass per unit of leaf area
Reference: Based on typical SLN of 0.5-1.5 gN m-2 for C4 grasses.
Based on C4 physiology (lower Rubisco, ~33% N in protein, 3.31 C:N).
Sage, R. F. (2004). New Phytologist, 143(1), 4-16. (Context for C4 N-use).

variable: typical Carbon mass ratio of rubisco enzyme to total leaf protein
Reference: Feller et al. (2008). J Exp Botany, 59(7), 1615-1624. (Notes Rubisco is ~5-9% of total leaf N in C4 plants).
C4 plants require far less Rubisco protein than C3 plants.

variable: typical Cholorophyll carbon in bundle sheath
Reference: Typical C4 partitioning (10-25% of total Chl).
Edwards, G. E., & Walker, D. A. (1983). C3, C4: mechanisms...
Ghannoum, O., et al. (2005). Plant, Cell & Environment, 28(8), 980-993.

variable: typical Cholorophyll carbon in mesophyll
Reference: Typical C4 partitioning (75-90% of total Chl).
Edwards, G. E., & Walker, D. A. (1983). C3, C4: mechanisms...
Ghannoum, O., et al. (2005). Plant, Cell & Environment, 28(8), 980-993.

Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.
Long, S. P. (1999). Photosynthesis in C4 plants. (Context for *Miscanthus*).
Similar to other C4 monocots like Maize.

variable: typical Maximum electron transport rate at 25oC
unit: umol e- s-1 m-2 leaf area
Reference: Wullschleger, S. D. (1993). Environmental Pollution, 83(1-2), 137-162.

variable: typical Intercellular-to-atmospheric CO2 concentration ratio (Ci/Ca)
Reference: von Caemmerer, S., & Furbank, R. T. (2003). Photosynthesis Research, 77(2-3), 191-211.
Fundamental trait of C4 photosynthesis.

variable: typical annual Gross Primary Production (GPP)
Reference: C4 perennial grasses (e.g., *Miscanthus*, *Panicum*) are among the most productive ecosystems.
Long, S. P., et al. (2006). Science, 312(5779), 1508-1512. (Context for bioenergy grasses).
Scurlock, J. M. O., et al. (2002). Global Change Biology, 8(1), 20-36.

Reference: Similar to other C4 monocots (Maize).
Doussan, C., et al. (1998). Annals of Botany, 81(2), 225-232. (Context for monocot hydraulics).

variable: typical Radial resistance per m2 root surface area for water uptake
Reference: Similar to other C4 monocots (Maize).

Reference: Similar to C4 monocots (Maize).

Reference: Similar to C4 monocots (Maize).

Reference: General range for C4 monocots (e.g., Maize).

variable: typical fine root branching frequency
Reference: General range for C4 monocots (e.g., Maize).
Pagès, L., et al. (2004). Plant and Soil, 258(1), 1-21.

variable: typical Half saturation Km for root uptake of NO3
Reference: Typical HATS range for C4 monocots.
York, L. M., et al. (2016). Journal of Experimental Botany, 67(16), 4931-4944.

variable: Saturated specific carboxylation rate by Rubisco at 25oC
Reference: Sage, R. F. (2002). Oecologia, 132(4), 481-495. (C4 kcat is generally higher than C3).

variable: typical Leaf area index
Reference: This range reflects values from a single regrowth cycle (low end) to a peak in a highly productive, irrigated field (high end).

variable: typical Leaf area index
Reference: This range represents mature temperate evergreen and dense conifer forests.

variable: typical Leaf area index
Reference: This is a typical range for a productive clover pasture, which is generally less dense than an alfalfa monoculture.

variable: typical Leaf area index
Reference: Peak LAI for cotton crops under typical to good irrigation and nitrogen management.

variable: typical Leaf area index
Reference: This is a typical range for a mature, productive maize crop at its peak vegetative stage.

variable: typical Leaf area index
Reference: Based on Green Area Index (GAI) values for mature oat canopies around the panicle emergence stage.

variable: typical Leaf area index
Reference: This range is typical for wet sedge tundra environments.

variable: typical Leaf area index
Reference: This range covers the optimal LAI for yield (low end) to the maximum observed peak LAI in productive fields (high end).

variable: typical Leaf area index
Reference: This range reflects values from typical to high-density winter wheat canopies at their peak.

variable: typical Leaf area index
Reference: This range is representative of a productive, managed temperate grassland or pasture, as opposed to a sparse, natural grassland.

variable: typical Leaf area index
Reference: This range is representative of a productive, managed temperate grassland or pasture.

variable: typical Leaf area index
Reference: This range is based on the typical peak values for C3 annual crops like oats and winter wheat.

variable: typical Leaf area index
Reference: This range reflects highly productive C4 grasses, such as *Miscanthus*, which can achieve a canopy density up to double that of maize.
